Dialogue:
EQ: Hello!  
AJ: Hello!  
EQ: Did you go back to your hometown this year?  
AJ: No, my parents' house is very close. Did you go back home for Obon?  
EQ: Yes, I did. My husband's mother is elderly, so we visited her.  
AJ: Did you travel by train or by car?  
EQ: By car. It was from the 14th to the 17th, so it wasn’t crowded.  
AJ: Good timing. Do you visit gravesites as well?  
EQ: No, since the welcoming fire was already done on the 14th.  
AJ: My family doesn't observe traditions like visiting graves or Obon.  
EQ: My family didn’t either because my father was the fourth son.  
AJ: Different families have different traditions.  
EQ: Does the number of children affect it?  
AJ: The eldest usually inherits the family line.  
EQ: Does living outside the prefecture impact it too?  
AJ: Yes, proximity influences visits.  
EQ: Distance makes it hard to visit.  
AJ: Holidays are usually the time to go back if it's far.  
EQ: Because of COVID-19, I avoided going back for about a year and a half.  
AJ: Travel may have increased now that restrictions have lifted.  
EQ: The expressway was crowded on the 14th.  
AJ: Post-Obon U-turn rush.  
EQ: It’s been five days since I got home, and I'm still okay.  
AJ: Symptoms usually appear within three days.  
EQ: It's crucial to avoid it for the family's sake.  
AJ: Some had to recuperate at home as hospitals were full.  
EQ: My brother in Tokyo received food supplies.  
AJ: Hotel quarantine food isn't great, but they are distributing a lot.  
EQ: Mostly ready-to-eat meals, with fresh foods bought online. Convenient.  
AJ: Online options are helpful.

EQ: Good evening.  
BO: Hello. How can I assist you tonight?  
EQ: Have you done anything enjoyable recently?  
BO: I attended a summer festival last Sunday.  
EQ: Was it crowded?  
BO: Yes, it was crowded. I saw many artists I like.  
EQ: I've never been to one. Can you tell me more?  
BO: Do you enjoy listening to music?  
EQ: I like it, but not as much recently.  
BO: You might enjoy festivals with both Western and Japanese music.  
EQ: Where was this festival held?  
BO: It was at Summer Sonic in Makuhari.  
EQ: The venue must have been large.  
BO: Yes, several stages. I walked all day.  
EQ: That sounds like good exercise.  
BO: Yes, I walked over 20,000 steps.  
EQ: That's a lot! You must have been hungry.  
BO: Yes, there were many food stalls, and I ate quite a bit.  
EQ: Do people sing along during the performances?  
BO: Yes, especially during performances of overseas artists.  
EQ: Did you recognize any of the overseas artists?  
BO: I don't usually listen to Western music, but their performances were powerful.  
EQ: What's your favorite type of music?  
BO: I really like ONE OK ROCK, which is why I went to the festival.  
EQ: It must have been exciting.  
BO: Yes, but it was very hot outside.  
EQ: Staying hydrated must have been important.  
BO: Yes, I drank plenty of fluids.  
EQ: Enjoying good food and music sounds perfect.  
BO: It was a very fulfilling experience.

EQ: Good evening.  
BO: Please proceed.  
EQ: Have you had any problems recently?  
BO: My body has been gradually getting heavier.  
EQ: Are you saying you have gained weight?  
BO: Yes, that's part of it. Also, my movements have become sluggish.  
EQ: Do you know the cause?  
BO: It might be a lack of exercise.  
EQ: I understand. Age can also cause us to become less active.  
BO: I see. I used to be very active, but now I'm not anymore.  
EQ: The coronavirus pandemic has made it harder to go out.  
BO: That's true. I plan to exercise at home, but I struggle to stay motivated.  
EQ: I decided to start going to a women-only gym recently.  
BO: A women-only gym sounds nice.  
EQ: It's a well-advertised place. It's comfortable because I don't have to worry about it.  
BO: Indeed, not having to worry about others is nice when it's just women.  
EQ: There are many elderly people too, and the staff often talks to me. It's enjoyable.  
BO: Are the staff members women as well?  
EQ: Yes, all the staff and clients are women.  
BO: That sounds good. I wish there was one near me.  
EQ: There are places that advertise 30-minute sessions.  
BO: There are many gyms around, but I've never seen a women-only one.  
EQ: It might not feel like a traditional gym. There are many elderly people, and it's just the right amount of exercise for me.  
BO: I agree. A hardcore gym might be too much for me as well.  
EQ: I used to overdo it and get tired, so this is just right.  
BO: Doing it at your own pace is best.  
EQ: It's convenient since it's only an hour from leaving home to coming back.  
BO: That sounds good. I might try it.  
EQ: Please search for it. Exercising will improve both your physical and mental condition.  
BO: Yes. Thank you for the information.

EQ: Hello.  
EV: Hello, nice to meet you.  
EQ: Do you like animals?  
EV: I don't dislike them, but since I have never had one, I can't really say.  
EQ: So, what comes to mind when you think of animals?  
EV: Is it a cat or a dog?  
EQ: I knew it. Do you want to keep one?  
EV: I don't really think so. It seems difficult.  
EQ: When I was a child, I had a dog.  
EV: Sounds good. Was it large?  
EQ: No, it was a normal size. It was a mixed breed.  
EV: Puppies are often cute.  
EQ: Yes, it started as a puppy. It followed me everywhere.  
EV: Watching it grow must have been rewarding.  
EQ: Yes. Some dogs used to roam freely.  
EV: I would be concerned about a dog barking and disturbing neighbors.  
EQ: Now everyone keeps them inside the house.  
EV: I used to hear a dog inside a house in my old neighborhood.  
EQ: It is common now for even large dogs to be kept indoors.  
EV: It might feel cramped for the dog.  
EQ: Keeping it outside was hard, but fun.  
EV: Walking a dog regularly can be time-consuming.  
EQ: It's impressive how people commit to daily walks.  
EV: Yes, it can take a lot of time.  
EQ: Maybe having pets is best when you're a child.  
EV: Right, as children have more time.  
EQ: It really enriches your heart.  
EV: Gaining experience young is important.  
EQ: I spent a lot of time playing with my dog.  
EV: That's nice.

EQ: Hello.  
EV: Hello.  
EQ: Do you prefer coffee or tea?  
EV: Tea.  
EQ: What kind of tea?  
EV: Barley tea.  
EQ: Good choice for summer.  
EV: Green tea upsets my stomach.  
EQ: Warm green tea helps my stomach.  
EV: Green tea has a diuretic effect.  
EQ: Green tea can help with constipation and dehydration.  
EV: I'll consider it.  
EQ: Coffee makes me use the restroom more often.  
EV: That's common.  
EQ: Did the caffeine work for you?  
EV: Not really.  
EQ: So, it didn’t act as a stimulant?  
EV: Correct.  
EQ: You can drink coffee before bed without issues.  
EV: Yes.  
EQ: I can't sleep after drinking coffee.  
EV: It affects you strongly.  
EQ: It also worsens my stomach pain.  
EV: That is an issue.  
EQ: I drink green tea instead.  
EV: I avoid coffee when I'm sleepy.  
EQ: What do you drink then?  
EV: Water.  
EQ: Water is a good choice.  
EV: It helps avoid restroom trips.

EQ: Hello!  
FW: Hello!  
EQ: Do you drink coffee or tea?  
FW: Mostly decaf coffee.  
EQ: Why decaf?  
FW: Caffeine affects my sleep.  
EQ: I avoid coffee at night too.  
FW: Do you drink tea?  
EQ: Yes, various kinds.  
FW: Favorite tea?  
EQ: Green tea.  
FW: Any specific type?  
EQ: No specific type, just used to it.  
FW: Shizuoka is famous for tea.  
EQ: Yes, I've tried Kukicha.  
FW: What's Kukicha?  
EQ: Tea made from stems.  
FW: Does it taste different?  
EQ: Yes, it's lighter.  
FW: Interesting.  
EQ: Tea has vitamins, good for skin.  
FW: Green tea has many vitamins.  
EQ: Also helps my stomach.  
FW: Makes you feel better?  
EQ: Yes, comforting when unwell.  
FW: I usually drink it cold but will switch to hot tea now.  
EQ: In summer, I drink barley tea. Warm tea is calming.  
FW: Warm tea is relaxing.  
EQ: I need to buy more tea soon.  
FW: Enjoying tea more is a good idea.

EQ: Hello!  
DF: Hello!  
EQ: What time did you wake up today?  
DF: I woke up around 8 o'clock today.  
EQ: Is it later than weekdays?  
DF: Yes, a little later.  
EQ: I’ve been struggling to wake up in the morning lately.  
DF: I understand. I'm not a morning person either.  
EQ: The cooler weather makes me oversleep.  
DF: It does make it easy to sleep in.  
EQ: I took out the comforter yesterday.  
DF: It might get cold again soon.  
EQ: I need to start swapping out my clothes soon.  
DF: True, summer clothes might not be wearable much longer.  
EQ: That would be unfortunate if they were new summer clothes.  
DF: Yes, like my T-shirts and tank tops.  
EQ: You could wear those with a jacket on top.  
DF: Good idea.  
EQ: You can focus on what you want to show.  
DF: I'll try that! Did you buy any fall clothes?  
EQ: Not yet, but I plan to soon.  
DF: I was looking online and now I want some.  
EQ: Gathering information first is helpful.  
DF: Yes, I often buy things after seeing them online, or just buy them online directly.  
EQ: I like online shopping too. Any recommended shops?  
DF: I often use ZOZO TOWN.  
EQ: ZOZO TOWN is nice, isn't it? But I haven't bought from there yet.  
DF: It's easy to search, though shipping fees apply.  
EQ: No free shipping, huh? Still, I'll take a look!  
DF: Please do!

EQ: Hello!  
DF: Hello!  

EQ: Is COVID-19 spreading recently?  
DF: It's calmer in Tokyo now, but I caught it last month.  

EQ: I see. Can you describe your symptoms?  
DF: I had throat discomfort, then pain.  

EQ: Did you have a fever?  
DF: Yes, it peaked at the high 37 degrees Celsius but subsided in a day.  

EQ: Thank you for sharing. Sorry if it's painful to recall.  
DF: It's fine! My throat hurt, but I kept my appetite.  

EQ: I'm worried as it hasn't been resolved.  
DF: Understandable. Throat discomfort can be a sign to watch for.  

EQ: I'll be cautious about my throat.  
DF: Good idea. Infection can happen anytime now.  

EQ: At hair salons, they suggest not wearing masks. Why is that?  
DF: Possibly for convenience during procedures like coloring.  

EQ: It seems inconvenient for coloring.  
DF: Especially around the ears. I prefer silent salons as I'm not very talkative there.  

EQ: I usually chat with my stylist. It's important to be considerate.  
DF: Absolutely! I recently cut my hair short.  

EQ: That's a significant change.  
DF: Yes, it's been a while. It's much easier now.  

EQ: Did your mindset change?  
DF: Yes, I needed a change. The pandemic has been quite depressing.  

EQ: You must feel refreshed. The humidity has been high lately.  
DF: True, it gets humid when a typhoon is approaching.  

EQ: Humidity makes my hair frizz.  
DF: It can be hard to manage.  

EQ: My hair texture seems to have changed.  
DF: That can happen.

EQ: Hello!
EV: Hello, nice to meet you.
EQ: Do you have any siblings?
EV: Yes, one younger sister.
EQ: So, you're the older brother? I'm the younger sister.
EV: Correct.
EQ: I have an older brother who is three years older than me.
EV: I see. I am 6 years apart from my sister.
EQ: That's quite a gap. Do you enjoy having conversations?
EV: No, I don't initiate conversations. They are talkative.
EQ: Isn't it nice that your younger sister talked to you?
EV: At home, I preferred being alone. It was annoying when I was concentrating.
EQ: I understand.
EV: Now that we don't live together, the distance is good.
EQ: I also prefer being alone.
EV: Occasional interaction is best.
EQ: When we are together, we argue.
EV: We’re different types.
EQ: Completely different. Now we communicate at a moderate distance.
EV: The distance feels right.
EQ: If it's the same gender, it might be different. With a three-year gap and different genders, it's subtle.
EV: Our hobbies were different. The age gap made it harder to get along.
EQ: It was painful to be seen as immature.
EV: Being three years apart isn't a big difference now.
EQ: True. Three years in childhood is different from three years in adulthood.
EV: Completely different. Some younger people seem mature.
EQ: Nowadays, I don't consider age differences much.
EV: It depends on the person. I get nervous around much older people.
EQ: I get nervous around much younger people.
EV: That's the other way around.

EQ: Hello!  
BV: Hello! How can I assist you today?  
EQ: Do you watch videos often?  
BV: Yes, I often watch video streams. How about you?  
EQ: I also watch YouTube often!  
BV: What types of videos do you enjoy watching?  
EQ: Mostly stretching, audition shows, and cooking.  
BV: That sounds interesting. Could you tell me more about audition programs?  
EQ: Sure! It's like "Got Talent" on America's AGT.  
BV: Oh, the famous one?  
EQ: Yes, Susan Boyle is famous from it.  
BV: Is it entertaining? I haven't seen it.  
EQ: It's really interesting. Various people appear, from small children to adults.  
BV: That sounds fascinating. What kind of performances are featured?  
EQ: Songs, dances, and other things.  
BV: I see. YouTube indeed has a variety of videos.  
EQ: It's very convenient. Recently, I've been cooking while watching YouTube.  
BV: That's productive. What have you cooked recently?  
EQ: A Taiwanese castella cake.  
BV: What is Taiwanese castella like?  
EQ: Fluffy and chewy with gentle sweetness.  
BV: That sounds delicious! Can you make that at home?  
EQ: Yes, I made it with a rice cooker.  
BV: Was it delicious?  
EQ: Yes, it was quite good. Search 'Taiwan castella' for recipes.  
BV: I will look into it.  
EQ: I used rice flour instead of wheat flour, and it turned out well.  
BV: Isn't making sweets with rice flour difficult?  
EQ: It can be, but I've started using rice flour regularly.  
BV: That's impressive! Your cooking skills are admirable.
